subtopics.title: Introduction to Polynomials
subtopics.content:
Introduction

A polynomial is an algebraic expression consisting of variables, coefficients, and non-negative integer powers of variables combined using addition, subtraction, and multiplication.

Examples:

2x³ + 3x² - 5x + 7

x² + 4x + 4

Polynomials are one of the most important topics in algebra because they appear in equations, curves, and real-world models.

subtopics.title: Degree of a Polynomial
subtopics.content:
Degree of a Polynomial

The degree of a polynomial is the highest power of the variable.

Examples:

3x² + 5x + 7 → degree = 2

2x⁴ - x³ + 8 → degree = 4

subtopics.title: Types of Polynomials
subtopics.content:
Types of Polynomials

Based on degree:

  • Linear Polynomial: Degree = 1 → e.g., 2x + 3
  • Quadratic Polynomial: Degree = 2 → e.g., x² - 4x + 4
  • Cubic Polynomial: Degree = 3 → e.g., x³ - 2x + 1

subtopics.title: Zeros of a Polynomial
subtopics.content:
Zeros of a Polynomial

A zero of a polynomial p(x) is a value of x for which p(x) = 0.

Example: For p(x) = x² - 9, zeros are x = 3 and x = -3.

subtopics.title: Relationship Between Zeros and Coefficients
subtopics.content:
Relationship Between Zeros and Coefficients

For quadratic polynomial ax² + bx + c:

Sum of zeros, α + β = -b/a

Product of zeros, αβ = c/a

For cubic polynomial ax³ + bx² + cx + d:

Sum of zeros, α + β + γ = -b/a

Sum of product of zeros taken two at a time = c/a

Product of zeros = -d/a

subtopics.title: Division Algorithm
subtopics.content:
Division Algorithm

If a polynomial p(x) is divided by another polynomial g(x), then

p(x) = g(x) · q(x) + r(x)

where,

  • q(x) = quotient polynomial
  • r(x) = remainder polynomial (degree of r(x) < degree of g(x))

questions.question: Degree of 7x⁴–3x²+2x–9:
questions.explanation: The degree of a polynomial is the highest power of the variable. In 7x⁴–3x²+2x–9, the highest power is 4.

questions.question: Which is linear?
questions.explanation: A linear polynomial has degree 1. 2x+7 is linear because the highest power of x is 1.

questions.question: Zeros of x²–16:
questions.explanation: x²–16 = (x–4)(x+4) = 0. So x = 4 or x = -4. The zeros are ±4.

questions.question: For p(x)=x²–5x+6, sum & product of zeros:
questions.explanation: For ax²+bx+c, sum of zeros = -b/a and product = c/a. Here a=1, b=-5, c=6. So sum = -(-5)/1 = 5 and product = 6/1 = 6.

questions.question: If zeros are 2 and 3, polynomial is:
questions.explanation: If zeros are 2 and 3, the polynomial is (x-2)(x-3) = x²-3x-2x+6 = x²-5x+6.

questions.question: For 2x²+3x–5, sum of zeros =
questions.explanation: For ax²+bx+c, sum of zeros = -b/a. Here a=2, b=3. So sum = -3/2.

questions.question: Which is NOT a polynomial?
questions.explanation: 2x³ + 1/x is not a polynomial because it contains 1/x, which is equivalent to x⁻¹. Polynomials can only have non-negative integer powers of variables.

questions.question: For x³–3x²+3x–1, one zero is:
questions.explanation: x³–3x²+3x–1 = (x-1)³. So x = 1 is a zero (with multiplicity 3).

questions.question: If x²+kx+6 has zeros –2, –3 → k=?
questions.explanation: If zeros are –2 and –3, the polynomial is (x+2)(x+3) = x²+3x+2x+6 = x²+5x+6. Comparing with x²+kx+6, we get k = 5.

questions.question: (x³–4x) ÷ (x–2), remainder =
questions.explanation: x³–4x = x(x²–4) = x(x–2)(x+2). So (x³–4x) ÷ (x–2) = x(x+2) = x²+2x with remainder 0.
